title: 103_s1187
content: The "Civilian Facilities Closure and Realignment Act of 1993" aims to reduce unnecessary spending in the Federal Government by closing or realigning duplicative, wasteful, or unnecessary civilian facilities. This includes facilities with costs outweighing benefits or those that do not serve a legitimate goal or mission of the administering agency. An independent commission called the "Civilian Facilities Closure and Realignment Commission" is established to carry out duties specified in the Act. The Commission consists of seven members appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Senate by January 1, 1994. The President consults with various leaders in selecting individuals for nominations to the Commission. The President appoints seven members to the Civilian Facilities Closure and Realignment Commission with Senate approval. The President designates one member as Chairman. Members serve until December 31, 1995, and can only be removed for cause. Meetings are open to the public, and all proceedings are accessible to Congress. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. (g) Pay and Travel Expenses.--Each member, other than the Chairman, shall be paid at a rate equal to the daily equivalent of the minimum annual rate of basic pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule under section 5315 of title 5, United States Code. The Chairman shall be paid at a rate equal to the daily equivalent of the minimum annual rate of basic pay for level III of the Executive Schedule under section 5314 of title 5, United States Code. Members shall also receive travel expenses, including per diem. Members receive travel expenses, including per diem, in accordance with specific sections of the United States Code. The Commission appoints a Director of Staff who must not have been a Federal employee in the past year. The Director is paid at the rate of basic pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Director can appoint additional personnel with Commission approval, without following competitive service appointment rules. The Commission can appoint personnel without following competitive service rules, and they may be paid without regard to certain pay rate provisions. Federal departments can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Comptroller General can provide assistance to the Commission. The Commission can procure temporary services by contract if funds are available. The Commission can appoint personnel without competitive service rules and pay them without certain pay rate provisions. Federal departments can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Comptroller General can provide assistance. The Commission may procure temporary services by contract or lease space and acquire personal property if funds are available. Funds are authorized to be appropriated for the Commission's duties, remaining available until expended. The Commission will terminate on December 31, 1995. SEC. 4. RECOMMENDATIONS AND REPORT FOR CIVILIAN FACILITY CLOSURES AND REALIGNMENTS. Each executive agency head must submit recommendations for closing or realigning civilian facilities by June 1, 1994. The Office of Management and Budget will provide cost estimates for implementing these recommendations. The Commission will review the agency recommendations and conduct public hearings. The Commission will conduct public hearings on recommendations and submit a report to the President by June 1, 1995, containing findings, recommendations for closures and realignments of Federal facilities, and proposed legislation. The Commission has the authority to make changes to agency recommendations. The Commission has the authority to make changes to agency recommendations, including adding facilities to closure or realignment lists. Changes must be published in the Federal Register and a public hearing conducted before submitting recommendations to the President. The Commission can modify agency recommendations for facility realignment or closure. Any differences must be explained in a report to the President and Congress. The Commission must provide information to Congress upon request. The Comptroller General of the United States has specific responsibilities. The Comptroller General of the United States assists the Commission in reviewing executive agencies' recommendations and submits a detailed analysis to Congress. The President must approve or disapprove the report by September 1, 1995, for legislative action. If the President disapproves the report, specific issues and objections must be reported to the Commission and Congress. The Commission can modify the report based on the President's concerns and must submit the final report to Congress within 30 days for legislative action. Congressional consideration of Commission report. Implementation bills, introduced after a final report is submitted to Congress, must contain proposed legislation without modification. Session days are when both the Senate and House of Representatives are in session. Implementation bills must be introduced in the Senate and House of Representatives by designated members or leaders. The bills will be referred to relevant committees for review. If a committee fails to report on the bill within 15 session days, it may be discharged. After 15 session days, if a committee fails to report on an implementation bill, it will be discharged and placed on the House calendar. On the fifth session day after the committee's report or discharge, any Member can move to proceed to consider the bill, with all points of order waived. The motion to proceed with the implementation bill is highly privileged and not debatable. It is not amendable, subject to postponement, or consideration of other business. Once agreed to, the respective House will immediately consider the bill without interruption. Debate on the bill is limited to 10 hours, divided equally between the Majority Leader. The implementation bill debate is limited to 10 hours, divided between the Majority Leader and Minority Leader. Amendments are not allowed, but a motion to limit debate is permitted. Other motions like postponement or reconsideration are not in order. The final vote on the bill will occur after a single quorum call. Appeals on Chair decisions regarding the bill's procedure can be made. The implementation bill debate is limited to 10 hours, with no amendments allowed. A motion to limit debate is permitted, and the final vote occurs after a single quorum call. Appeals on Chair decisions can be made. Implementation bills from one House to another follow specific procedures without debate. The implementation bill debate is limited to 10 hours with no amendments allowed. The final vote on the implementation bill from the other House is required, except for revenue bills originating in the House of Representatives. Once the implementation bill from the other House is dealt with, the original House's bill cannot be considered. This section is enacted by Congress as part of the rules of each House for the procedure to be followed. The rules for an implementation bill in the House supersede other rules if inconsistent, recognizing each House's right to change its rules regarding procedures. SEC. 6. DISTRIBUTION OF ASSETS. Proceeds from asset sales under an Act shall reduce the Federal deficit and be deposited in the Treasury as general receipts. SEC. 7. ADDITIONAL APPROPRIATIONS BASED ON AGENCY SAVINGS. In the fiscal year following a recommendation, each agency should receive an appropriation of at least 25 percent of estimated administrative savings to improve management, efficiency, or productivity. The appropriated funds are in addition to the agency's regular budget and can be used at the discretion of the agency head. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Such sums as necessary are authorized to carry out the provisions of this Act.
